message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The displacement and hypoplasia of the left thumb along with the symptoms suggest that the most likely diagnosis is Tetralogy of Fallot. This is supported by the presence of a right ventricular lift, single S2, and harsh systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border on examination. This is confirmed by the chest x-ray which shows a boot-shaped heart. Transposition of great vessels would present with severe cyanosis and no murmur. Ventricular septal defect is unlikely to cause cyanosis unless it is large, and transient tachypnea of the newborn is a respiratory condition that does not involve heart abnormalities.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The cyanosis, hypoplastic and displaced thumb, right ventricular lift, single S2, and harsh systolic ejection murmur all suggest Tetralogy of Fallot. The chest X-ray shows a boot-shaped heart, which is a characteristic finding in Tetralogy of Fallot. Transposition of great vessels would not have the same physical findings. Ventricular septal defect would not explain the cyanosis and other physical findings. Transient tachypnea of the newborn would not cause the cardiac abnormalities seen in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The cyanosis, respiratory distress, and heart murmur suggest a congenital heart defect. The displaced and hypoplastic thumb is a characteristic finding in Tetralogy of Fallot. The chest X-ray may also show a boot-shaped heart. Transposition of great vessels would have a single S1 and S2, but no murmur. Ventricular septal defect would have a harsh holosystolic murmur, not limited to systole. Transient tachypnoea of the newborn would not cause cyanosis, heart murmur or thumb abnormalities.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The displacement and hypoplasia of the left thumb, along with the symptoms, suggest that the baby has Tetralogy of Fallot. This condition includes a ventricular septal defect (which causes the heart murmur), pulmonary stenosis (which causes the right ventricular lift), overriding aorta, and right ventricular hypertrophy, leading to cyanosis. Transposition of great vessels would have a normal S2 and the X-ray does not show the characteristic egg on string appearance. Ventricular septal defect would not explain the other symptoms. Transient tachypnoea of the newborn would not have the other cardiac findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The displacement and hypoplasia of the left thumb suggest a genetic syndrome like VACTERL association, which is often associated with Tetralogy of Fallot. The presentation of cyanosis, respiratory distress, and a loud systolic murmur are all consistent with this diagnosis. The chest X-ray also shows a boot-shaped heart, which is a hallmark finding in Tetralogy of Fallot. Transposition of great vessels presents with early cyanosis and a normal heart size on chest X-ray. Ventricular septal defect may present with a murmur but would not cause cyanosis. Transient tachypnea of the newborn does not cause cyanosis or heart murmurs.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of hypoplastic thumb and a diagnosed congenital heart disease indicate Tetralogy of Fallot as the most likely diagnosis. The chest X-ray may also show characteristic findings such as “boot-shaped” heart.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The chest X-ray and clinical findings suggest Tetralogy of Fallot. Transposition of great vessels would present with cyanosis in the first few hours of life, while the baby appears comfortable after 1 day. A ventricular septal defect would not explain the pulmonary stenosis causing the murmur. Transient tachypnoea of the newborn would not present with cyanosis and the other findings listed.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including cyanosis, hypoplastic thumb, and harsh systolic ejection murmur suggest Tetralogy of Fallot. The chest X-ray also shows a boot-shaped heart, which is a characteristic finding in Tetralogy of Fallot. Transposition of great vessels would have a single loud S2 and a soft, non-radiating murmur. Ventricular septal defect would have a holosystolic murmur and no cyanosis. Transient tachypnea of the newborn would not present with a heart murmur or cyanosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and findings point towards Tetralogy of Fallot. The cyanosis of the oral mucosa indicates poor oxygenation, which is further confirmed by a low pulse oximetry reading. The displaced and hypoplastic thumb is a specific finding in Tetralogy of Fallot. The right ventricular lift and harsh murmur also support the diagnosis. Transposition of great vessels and ventricular septal defect would both present with a different pattern of murmur and S2 splitting. Transient tachypnoea of the newborn would not present with a cardiac murmur.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings are consistent with Tetralogy of Fallot, which includes displacement and hypoplasia of the thumb, right ventricular lift, single S2, and a systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border. Transposition of great vessels and ventricular septal defect may have cyanosis but do not have the same combination of physical findings. Transient tachypnoea of the newborn would not cause cyanosis or the other physical findings.
